content.body: Hey peeps, I am trying to understand how to read the following document to determine the correct (or rather expected) behaviour

I am trying to understand the URL Specification in particular (https://url.spec.whatwg.org/), and determine the expected result for a new URL that is not special (e.g. has a scheme of foo://, facebook://, my-app://)

On Chrome, Firefox and other browsers currently creating a new URL of such a type will set the pathname of the non-special URL to everything after the colon prepended by a double slash (i.e. //, that is part of the URL and not URI), and the hostname and host is set to null
however on NodeJS the following happens
I just wanted to understand how to read the specification properly to understand which one is the compliant one, and be able to reference it.

* On Chrome, Firefox and other browsers currently creating a new URL of such a type will set the pathname of the non-special URL to everything after the colon prepended by a double slash (i.e. //, that is part of the URL and not URI), and the hostname and host is not set

m.new_content.body: On Chrome, Firefox and other browsers currently creating a new URL of such a type will set the pathname of the non-special URL to everything after the colon prepended by a double slash (i.e. //, that is part of the URL and not URI), and the hostname and host is not set
